job_title: Member Services in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Higher staff are very inclusive and friendly. They are more than willing to help your, and they'll be as flexible as they can for your schedule. Class schedule come before work schedules.
cons: May have to deal with angry customers and student staff mistakes. Can only work up to 28 hours (less if you are an international student)

job_title: Project Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Best reasons to work at University of Missouri-St Louis is the academic environment and making an impact on the students on campus. They do provide health insurance, retirement, & personal, vacation, & sick time available.
cons: Their pay rate. Their salary ranges are well below the average range for their staff/employees & they are unwilling to raise the rates. There has been an exorbitant amount of staff members leaving University of Missouri-St Louis due to their pay rate. They also have minimum internal staff support positions & are unwilling to pay for the personnel infrastructure. So many employees are leaving for better pay elsewhere. While UMSL will pile on more tasks onto those who stay by combining 2-3 previous positions into one. It is very hard to get all assigned tasks done within the work week. They also most/all staff positions do require on site work.

review_title: Was happy here until I took off my Rose-Colored glasses
job_title: Communications Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Loved working with the students Employees are very kind and welcoming
cons: Staff is severely underpaid and overworked Higher Ups/HR would prefer a higher performing professional that deserves higher pay to leave the company and go through the hassle of hiring someone less qualified for cheaper.

job_title: Carpenter/Flyman in Saint Louis, MO
pros: At a time in my life when I needed a family, the touhill gave me one. It’s hard work but it’s an honor to do it alongside a family.
cons: It’s hard work, it’s long hours, but it’s worth every minute I put in

job_title: Lifeguard/Swim Instructor in Normandy, MO
pros: Great work culture, and great opportunities for students to grow their experience working with patrons.
cons: Compensation is good for a student, but not for a professional employed.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Had perks as a student and access to the archives
cons: No health insurance for graduate students

job_title: Assistant Professor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Very dedicated colleagues who are student centered
cons: Teaching only night classes was tough.

job_title: Office Support III in Saint Louis, MO
pros: WFH flexibility, coworkers, student relationships
cons: low pay, disorganization across the system, negativity,

job_title: Project Director in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Have learned a lot about mental health. Good people work there.
cons: Pay, no perks that come with a private employer. Rules subject to UM system and not localized.

review_title: Great mission, great school, challenging times
job_title: Director, Advancement Services in Saint Louis, MO
pros: People in IT and in Finance were among some of the best people I have ever worked with, both in skills and in being good people.
cons: Challenging times, and a lot of institutional knowledge has been lost. For culture and values rating, this varied greatly depending on the department under consideration. Most were great, but two departments had members whose culture and values were vastly different from what I found to be acceptable in general, much less in a work environment.

job_title: Academic Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good starting job with partial work from home opportunity depending on your department. People are nice and welcoming.
cons: Unfair/unequal salaries, not much opportunity for growth (via promotion or salary increase), staff is undervalued - more faculty focused, and benefits need improvement.

job_title: Telefund Caller in University City, St. Louis, MO
pros: The manager at the time was motivational, friendly, caring, and clear about expectations. As student callers, it was sometimes nerve wracking to ask for money over the phone, but our manager would remind us of the skills we were building by sticking to the task. Scheduling was also very flexible. We essentially created our own schedules and were always told to prioritize our education.
cons: None that I can think of—this was a great student job!

job_title: Academic Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The Academic Advisor job is good for someone wanting to start their professional career. It will open up the door for other opportunities.
cons: Not a good paying position. Not meant to be a longterm position.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: UMSL is one of the best places I've ever worked. coworkers and management!
cons: Wages are not so great and raises are very little. But the benefits are pretty good.

pros: Benefits, supervisor, access to resources and professional development, chances for growth

job_title: Program Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Salary is decent. Benefits are decent.
cons: Criticism on a daily. Overbearing manager, that doesn't let you have space to grow.

job_title: Student Assistant CSM in University City, St. Louis, MO

review_title: Terrible management from higher-level administration in an otherwise very good university.
job_title: Lecturer in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Flexible schedule, health benefits, autonomy, student body. I find the teaching to be very rewarding because the students are kind and down-to-earth. There's a lot of diversity in the student body. There are also more full-time positions and fewer adjuncts compared to other area colleges. It offers a quality education from a research institution at a better price than other colleges. There is a focus on good teaching skills and student satisfaction.
cons:
After 20 years of dedicated service, I was severely bullied and lied about by a new boss. I was surprised how people who knew me well could believe these mistruths. But the ambience is negative. Human resources doesn't help faculty members so there was little support. Basically, I was told I could file a grievance but if I did, nobody would hire me in other departments. 

There is little interaction between units- they are silos. Also, chairs come in and do not transition, which makes for a lack of communication.

There's also very little appreciation and recognition for hard work.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Good Place, was not a long term destination for me

job_title: Accountant in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: Good Experience While Studying as a Student

review_title: Amazing university that has large impact

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Saint Louis, MO

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Diverse and welcoming, friendly environment
cons: Did not have a bad experience

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
-Good benefits 
-Worked next to some great people
cons:
-Worst management and leadership I've ever seen. I've worked at a number of different schools and companies and I was flabbergasted at the level of incompetence I saw on a daily basis.
-Organizational structure is highly vertical.  Any form of collaboration is discouraged, even penalized.  
-Ambition to be superlative at your job comes across as a threat to upper management and will likely result in penalty or dismissal.  
-I came to work each and every day excited and energized, but left demoralized.  Work here and you'll likely feel the same way.
-You need to use vacation time and/or personal days for Christmas vacation (I wish I were kidding).

I can't express to you how much of a mistake it would be to get a job at UMSL.  Enrollment will continue to decline and the budget will remain in the red for at least the next decade.  If you get a job here, you're not only working for some of the worst management in higher education, you might be the victim of the next cycle of budget cuts.

job_title: Resident Advisor in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
This is a great first job.  You get well-rounded experience and perform so many different duties that it's honestly a great launch for a  resume. 
You also meet a lot of people.  
The training at the beginning of the year is extensive.
cons:
Though the Resident Advisor group is small, it has a lot of cliques. 
The job REALLY utilizes the "and other duties as assigned" bullet point. 
The staff asks for student feedback and opinions more than most jobs, I think, but often ignore the suggestions. (For example, staff members put returning RAs in the living communities they want them to go, but on the applications, RAs are asked to rank their preferences.)

job_title: Program Coordinator in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The health insurance and prescription coverage are actually pretty good compared to other universities in the area. Also, employees get a decent amount of paid time off, including one sick day a month, four personal days a year, and up to 22 vacation days (in addition to observed holidays.)
cons:
There are three major cons: 
1. There are always budget cuts. This creates a very, very stressful work environment, and when layoffs occur, increases workload for remaining staff members. UMSL is perpetually understaffed.
2. Pay raises are minimal. In my time at UMSL, the largest annual increase I received was 4%. Several years in a row, there were no increases whatsoever.
3. Upward mobility is very difficult for staff.

job_title: in Saint Louis, MO
pros:
Benefits are good: 75% of tuition if you want to take classes (50% off for spouse and dependents), United Health Care Plan ( Love! especially if you use the health savings plan and the reward benefits that give you an extra 450 per year), accumulating sick time and vacation time with 4 personal days.

There's also room for growth if you were wanting to move up but it's always about who you know. So talk to people and make sure they know your name (in a good way that is; not b/c you did something bad or made a mistake)
cons: Being on the bottom of the totem pole sucks. Everyone think they are above you and titles are very important. It's your job to do the things no one else wants to do (like clean up their mess and do their jobs)

review_title: Politics, low pay and a relaxed atmosphere
job_title: IT in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Very relaxed atmosphere, 75% off tuition for yourself, 50% off tuition for your children, paid day off on snow days, decent insurance, matching retirement funds.
cons: Many decisions are made by Columbia and then trickle down to the UMSL campus.  These decisions are not often in UMSLs best interest.  Additionally, directors and above make critical decisions with little to no input from those who will live with those decisions.  Pay is also well below average.  UMSL is always crying about lack of funds but a tremendous amount of money is spent on new buildings and special projects.  Departments spend money like its going out of style and it is frequently wasted in one form or another.

review_title: A lot of work for not a lot of pay, but good people
job_title: Teaching Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The staff and faculty at the University are generally invested, intelligent, and pleasant people to work with. The atmosphere isn't too stuffy.
cons: Having to pay for parking at the University is really annoying, especially since it's not like the area has a super great transportation alternative, and I guarantee not many of the people who work there live in the area.

review_title: UMSL really tries, but they're constantly limited by their budget realities
job_title: IT in Saint Louis, MO
pros: A lot of great people work here. UMSL is all about their students, and a lot of people buy in to the mission, which is great for the students. Many in administration care about the employees.
cons: Working at an organization where your jobs and your coworkers jobs are constantly threatened by budget realities is mentally draining. UMSL has the potential to be a great place to work. But when everyone is asked to do more with less every single year, and great employees are laid off in the face of constant budget shortfalls, it loses a lot of it luster.

job_title: in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Some supervisors give lots of autonomy to do my job.  Loved working with students. Very flexible hours.  Convenient to work and take classes.  Many jobs come with tuition assistance.
cons: Some supervisors are micro-managers.  Overall it was a very good experience through my different positions at the university.  I just need to run out the minimum word count now.

job_title: Coach in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Good people and a new marketing campaign that will help the University shed it's reputation of being a commuter school.
cons: Lots of Silo's - working independently and moving money from bucket to bucket around the organization.  5 years to vest in the "pension"

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: I work off-campus at an UMSL research institution. We have an incredibly flexible work schedule and culture. Many employees are able to work from home, and are able to set their own schedule. As an added bonus, you earn a lot of vacation time (17 days) per year. The work within the institute is very diverse, and there are opportunities to collaborate with other departments.
cons: It is hard to get a raise or get a promotion. As a consequence, many employees are compensated below market value. UMSL salaries are public and searchable on google.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Was there for three years. The staff is incredibly hit or miss. The people I worked with in my second department were high quality, and a pleasure to work with.
cons: The people I worked with in my first department, however, were not. The offices had about the same level of traffic, but the first one had involved front desk clerks that were unbelievably rude, advisors that would trash the students after they left the office, and overall a sense of apathy hung in the air.

job_title: Graduate Research Assistant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Excellent faculty to work with
cons: University admins lean away from keeping the university as an academic institution and try to run it more like a business...they considered cutting basic overworked departments instead of investing in them. Graduate student pay is terrible (as it is everywhere) and the university only subsidizes bad insurance plans.

job_title: Senior Lab Consultant in Saint Louis, MO
pros: Instructional Support Services (ISS) provides me with real world experiences while providing experience in management in the Senior Consultant role by tracking and delegating class schedules for hundreds of active classes for support each day.
cons: As ISS is a campus provided job, students are only allowed to work part time.

review_title: Your experience will totally depend on your department
job_title: Director in Saint Louis, MO
pros: If seeking a degree, you get 75% off tuition as an employee, your dependents will get 50% off tuition. Good pension plan and benefits. Employees have access to the optometry clinic. Opportunities for professional development (depending on your manager)
cons: Constant budget issues the entire time I worked there. Employees are always worried about layoffs. Administrative bloat, apathetic faculty in some departments, employees are not valued, negative environment.

job_title: Associate Professor Nursing in Saint Louis, MO
pros: The Dean makes all the difference - it was student center then with the Dean change it became all about the budget and her goals to the Provost.
cons: The leadership didn’t seem to mind when great numbers of experienced faculty left and board certification pass rates declined.

job_title: Support Staff in Saint Louis, MO
pros: good benefits and vacation/sick days, engaging work environment

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Saint Louis, MO

review_title: The most toxic culture in which I have ever worked.
